revision.text:
<!-- This article is a part of [[Wikipedia:WikiProject Aircraft]]. Please see [[Wikipedia:WikiProject Aircraft/page content]] for recommended layout. --> {|{{Infobox aircraft begin |name = Monocoupe 90 |image = Monocoupe90A.jpg |caption = Monocoupe 90A }}{{Infobox aircraft type |type = Light Trainer and Racer |manufacturer = [[Monocoupe Aircraft]] |designer = Don A. Luscombe |first flight = April 1, 1927 |introduced = 1928 |introduction= <!--date the aircraft will enter military or revenue service, if the aircraft is still in development --> |retired = <!--date the aircraft left military or revenue service. If vague or multiples, it probably should be skipped--> |status = <!--in most cases, this field is redundant; use it sparingly--> |primary user = [[Civil aviation|Civil Aviation]] |more users = [[USAAF]] |produced = <!--years in production, e.g. 1970-1999, if still in active use but no longer built--> |number built = 324 (all models) <ref>Simpson, 2001, p. 383</ref> |unit cost = |developed from = <!-- the aircraft which formed the basis for the topic type --> |variants with their own articles = <!-- variants OF the topic type --> }} |}
The '''Monocoupe 90''' was a two-seat, light cabin airplane built by [[Donald A. Luscombe]] for [[Monocoupe|Central States Aare Inc.]].<ref name="world">Eden and Moeng 2002 p. 993</ref> The first Monocoupe (Model 5) was built in an abandoned church in [[Davenport, Iowa]], and first flew on April 1, 1927.<ref name="virginia">[http://www.eaa231.org/Museum/Monocoupe/Monocoupe.htm Virginia Aviation Museum] accessed 30 September 2007</ref> Various models were in production until the late 1940s.
==Development== The ''Monocoupes'' were side-by-side two-seat lightplanes of mixed wood and steel-tube basic construction with fabric covering. A braced high-wing [[monoplane]] with fixed tailskid landing gear, and the reverse curve rear fuselage lines that were to become one of the signature identifier features of the Monocoupes.<ref name="world"/> The fuselage framework was built up of welded steel tubing in a rigid, triangular-framed [[Truss bridge#Warren truss|Warren truss]] form for the side panel structures, heavily faired to shape with [[duralumin|dural]] metal sheet formers and wooden fairing strips. The wings were built up of solid [[spruce]] spars with wing ribs of [[basswood]] webs and spruce cap-strips. The leading edges were covered with dural metal sheet and the entire framework was covered in fabric.<ref name="AVM">[http://www.airventuremuseum.org/collection/aircraft/Monocoupe%2090AW.asp Airventure Museum] accessed 2 October 2007</ref>
The aircraft was powered originally by either a 60 hp (45 kW) [[Anzani]] engine or the unsuccessful 65 hp (48 kW) [[Detroit Air Cat]] radial.<ref name="world"/> The '''Model 22''' was the first light aircraft awarded a [[type certificate]] (number 22) and in 1930 it was fitted with the [[Velie M-5]] 62 hp (46 kW) five-cylinder radial engine to become the '''Model 70'''.<ref name="virginia"/> [[File:Monocoupe 90 Rhinebeck NY 10.06.05R.jpg|thumb|right|1932-built Monocoupe 90 at [[Old Rhinebeck Aerodrome]] in 2005]] In 1930 Monocoupe introduced the '''Model 90''' with refined lines and a fuselage that was slightly longer and wider, this being sold in '''Model 90''' and '''Model 90A''' versions with a 90 hp (67 kW) [[Lambert R-266]] radial engine. The '''Monocoupe 90 DeLuxe''' introduced trailing edge flaps, wheel speed fairings and an improved engine cowling. The '''Model 90AF''' was fitted with a 115 hp (86 kW) [[Franklin (automobile)|Franklin]] engine. The '''Model 90AL''' had [[Avco Lycoming]] engines. The '''Model 90J''' was introduced in 1930 with a 90 hp (67 kW) [[Warner Scarab Jr]] engine.
The final two high performance Monocoupe models developed from the Model 90 were the '''Model 110''' with a 110 hp (82 kW) [[Warner Scarab]], and the '''Model 125''' with a 125-hp (93 kW) [[Kinner B-5]] engine. The [[Monocoupe 110 Special]] was a clipped wing racing aircraft. The [[Monocoupe]] '''Model 70V''' of 1932, had the low-powered 65-hp (48-kW) [[Velie M-5]] engine reintroduced to provide more economical operation at the cost of a fall in performance.<ref name="world"/>
In 1941 ''Monocoupe'' combined with three other companies to form [[Universal Molded Products Corp.]] 20 '''Model 90AFs''' were bought by the [[USAAF]], who designated them the '''Universal L-7''', for transfer to the [[Free French Forces]]. One was lost during delivery.<ref name="Meal">Fanatique de l'aviation n°370</ref> Aircraft production halted during World War II, resuming briefly in 1948-1950 under the name [[Monocoupe Airplane and Engine Corp.]]<ref name="smith">Bell, 2002, p. 207</ref>
The last of this remarkable line of two-seat aircraft was the '''Monocoupe D-145''' of 1934, a high-performance version with a slightly enlarged cabin and powered by a 145 hp (108 kW) [[Warner Scarab|Warner Super Scarab]] engine.<ref name="world"/>
==Variants== ;Monocoupe Model 5: prototype ;[[Monocoupe Model 22]]: 60 hp (45 kW) [[Anzani]] engine or 65 hp (48 kW) [[Detroit Air Cat]] radial.<ref name="world"/> ;[[Velie Monocoupe|Monocoupe Model 70]]: [[Velie M-5]] 62 hp (46 kW) five-cylinder radial engine<ref name="virginia"/> [[File:Monocoupe 113 (N8934).jpg|thumb|Monocoupe 113]] ;Monocoupe Model 113: revised landing gear and a number of improvements<ref name="world"/> ;Monocoupe Monoprep: dedicated trainer similar to the Monocoupe 113<ref name="world"/> ;Mnocoupe Monosport Model 1: air racing model, had a 110-hp (82 kW) Warner Scarab seven-cylinder radial engine<ref name="world"/> ;Monocoupe Monosport Model 2: air racing model, had a 100-hp (75 kW) [[Kinner K-5]] radial engine<ref name="world"/> [[File:Monocoupe 90A G-AFEL Biggin Hill 11.09.82 edited-3.jpg|right|thumb|Monocoupe 90A of 1937 at [[Biggin Hill Airport]], England in September 1982]] ;Monocoupe Model 90: longer wider fuselage<ref name="world"/> ;Monocoupe Model 90A: 90 hp (67 kW) [[Lambert R-266]] radial engine<ref name="world"/> ;Monocoupe 90 DeLuxe: trailing edge flaps, wheel speed fairings and an improved engine cowling<ref name="world"/> ;Monocoupe Model 90AF: 115 hp (86 kW) [[Franklin (automobile)|Franklin]] engine<ref name="world"/> ;Monocoupe Model 90AL: [[Avco Lycoming]] engine<ref name="world"/> [[File:Monocoupe D-145.jpg|thumb|right|Monocoupe D-145]] ;Monocoupe Model 90AW: with 145 hp Warner engine, Wing Span 32 ft. Length 20 ft. 5.75 in.<ref name="AVM"/> ;Monocoupe Model 110: 110 hp (82 kW) [[Warner Scarab]] engine<ref name="world"/> ;[[Monocoupe 110 Special|Monocoupe Model 110 Special]]: racing model, 110 hp (82 kW) [[Warner Scarab]] engine, shorter span ;Monocoupe Model 125: 125-hp (93 kW) [[Kinner B-5]] engine<ref name="world"/> ;Universal L-7: military version of the '''Model 90AF'''.<ref name="Fahey">U.S. Army Aircraft 1908-1946</ref> ;Monocoupe D-145: 145 hp (108 kW) [[Warner Scarab|Warner Super Scarab]] engine.<ref name="world"/>
==Operators== The majority of the Monocoupe 90s to be built were sold to and flown by private pilot owners.
;{{flag|Spain|1931}} *[[Spanish Republican Air Force]] - Monocoupe 90 A ;{{flag|France}} *[[Free French Forces]], later [[Armée de l'Air]] - Monocoupe 90 AF 19 delivered early 1943 by sea to Abu Sweir, [[Egypt]], to be reassembled by [[Royal Air Force|RAF]] MU 109.<ref name="Meal"/> Main delivery to create a flying school (GE 11) in Rayack, [[Syria]], opening September 1, 1943. The Monocoupe 90 was too sensitive to be used for basic training and many accidents occurred until school disbandment January 4, 1944.<ref name="Meal"/> One aircraft survived the war and remained on the French civil register until written-off in 1962.<ref name="X.Meal">Fanatique de l'aviation n°371</ref> 5 aircraft delivered to [[Madagascar]] in early September 1943 and operated by ''Escadrille d'Avions Sanitaires et de Liaison'' (EASL = Liaison and Medical Flight) based at Ivato.<ref name="X.Meal"/> EASL became ''Escadrille de Liaison et de Commandement'' (ELC) on January 1, 1944, then SAL-51 and last SLA-50. The last two Monocoupes were sold to local aéro-club in 1948.<ref name="X.Meal"/>
==Specifications (Model 90)== {{aircraft specifications <!-- if you do not understand how to use this template, please ask at [[Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Aircraft]] --> |plane or copter?=<!-- options: plane/copter --> plane |jet or prop?=<!-- options: jet/prop/both/neither --> prop <!-- Now, fill out the specs. Please include units where appropriate (main comes first, alt in parentheses). If an item doesn't apply leave it blank. For instructions on using |more general=, |more performance=, |power original=, and |thrust original= see [[Template talk:Aircraft specifications]]. --> |ref={{Citation needed|date=June 2011}} |crew= one, pilot |capacity= 1 passenger |length main= 20 ft 10 in |length alt= 6.35 m |span main= 32 ft 0 in |span alt= 9.76 m |height main= 6 ft 11 in |height alt= 2.11 m |area main= <!--ft²--> |area alt= <!--m²--> |airfoil= |empty weight main= 973 lb |empty weight alt= 441 kg |loaded weight main= 1,490 lb |loaded weight alt= 676 kg |useful load main= <!--lb--> |useful load alt= <!--kg--> |max takeoff weight main= <!--lb--> |max takeoff weight alt= <!--kg--> |more general= |engine (prop)=[[Lambert R-266]] |type of prop=[[radial engine]] |number of props=1 |power main= 90 hp |power alt= 67 kW |power original= |max speed main= 100 knots |max speed alt= 115 mph, 185 km/h |cruise speed main= <!--knots--> |cruise speed alt= <!--mph,km/h--> |never exceed speed main= <!--knots--> |never exceed speed alt= <!--mph,km/h--> |stall speed main= <!--knots--> |stall speed alt= <!--mph,km/h--> |range main= 470 nm |range alt= 540 miles, 869 km |ceiling main= 15,000 ft |ceiling alt= 4,573 m |climb rate main= <!--ft/min--> |climb rate alt= <!--m/s--> |loading main= <!--lb/ft²--> |loading alt= <!--kg/m²--> |thrust/weight= <!--a unitless ratio--> |power/mass main=0.06 hp/lb |power/mass alt= 0.10 kW/kg |more performance= |armament= |avionics= }}

ISBN 0-7607-3432-1. * [[James Charles Fahey|Fahey, James C.]] ''U.S. Army Aircraft 1908-1946''. Ships and Aircraft, Falls Church, VA. 1946. * Simpson, Rod. ''Airlife's World Aircraft'', Airlife Publishing, 2001. ISBN 1-84037-115-3 * Swanborough, F. G. and Bowers, Peter M.''United States Military Aircraft Since 1909''. Putnam New York, 1964. ISBN 0-85177-816-X. * Meal, X. ''Monocoupe L-74. Les petits oiseaux de la France Libre''. Le Fanatique de l'Aviation n° 370/371 (sept and oct 2000).
